item.title: £400 per household per year to achieve net zero? A bargain, surely? But…
item.description: Phil Goodwin points to new data that exposes the ‘absurdities’ of treating the carbon impact of the road programme, and its individual schemes, as trivially insignificant.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Phil Goodwin)

item.title: A time for sharing?
item.description: Planning how we cater for future personal transport needs, and in particular for the future of the private car.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Peter Stonham)

item.title: Do we know where we’re going?
item.description: History tells us that we very often just cannot see what is going to change our world, and our lives.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Peter Stonham)

item.title: This might turn out to be another significant moment
item.description: Arman Farahmand-Razavi offers his personal reflections on a forum that embraced the big issues of our time, and how it has reminded him of past gatherings of the sector’s leading thinkers.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Arman Farahmand-Razavi)

item.title: An important new dimension in talking about tackling climate change
item.description: Although this declaration is not legally binding, it opens up an important new dimension in the political and business sectors’ agenda in talking about tackling climate change.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Peter Stonham)

item.title: If you’re in a hole… it must be time to rethink Stonehenge scheme
item.description: Updated values would reveal the true cost of building a tunnel under Stonehenge, says Phil Goodwin. He urges National Highways to think again.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Phil Goodwin)

item.title: Pressures for change - to the context in which transport is considered - are only going to multiply
item.description: We should expect more elements of the transport landscape to be fought over as either ‘right or wrong’ for the future of the planet.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Peter Stonham)

item.title: The transport industry is not known for going too far beyond its boundaries for the top jobs
item.description: Who else is out there in the potential talent pool for the challenging new roles that securing the nation’s best transport future in a changing world is regularly throwing up.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Peter Stonham)

item.title: Whilst challenging the Government’s funding distribution model - the NIC has not been quite bold enough
item.description: A transport taxation and distribution re-think is surely now also very much due, with the expected pending diminution of the established fuel tax revenue model.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Peter Stonham)

item.title: Why we must recognise the true impact of climate change in transport appraisal
item.description: ‘Baseline’ forecasts should be urgently revised so they reflect the current trajectory of global warming.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Phil Goodwin)

item.title: Reshaping and rethinking our role, and its delivery
item.description: As we re-appear in a new format, after a summer break, the obvious need for a carefully curated and structured fortnightly take on UK transport has been clearer than ever.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Peter Stonham)

item.title: We are now facing two alternative futures, plus an untenable one
item.description: Phil Goodwin and Jillian Anable discuss the role of transport decarbonisation in addressing the impacts of climate change.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Phil Goodwin)

item.title: Time to get back to normal and kick-start business as usual?
item.description: The line on a graph called ‘business as usual’ has simply become meaningless. Yes, we plead, let us feel we can lead normal lives, but for planning and forecasting we cannot credibly translate that into a tenable description of normality.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Phil Goodwin)

item.title: Transport appraisal and planning in a time of imperatives
item.description: All discussion of strategic and local transport planning at present is seen through the lens of the urgent imperatives of the pandemic, which have changed the boundaries of policy in contradictory directions.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Phil Goodwin)

item.title: Driving change: travel in the 21st century
item.description: Some of the worst mistakes in transport investment have been supported by huge volumes of forecasts, surveys and studies, confidently published with little recognition of their inconsistencies and errors.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Phil Goodwin)
